f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:09): the only other heurisitic I thought of what checking the URL to see if it ended in .jpg, .png, .gif, etc. since linking a longdesc to an image is pointless. But that would have only caught one example that I found
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:10): re [D] links and longdesc, http://joeclark.org/book/sashay/serialization/Chapter06.html#d-links

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:10): that can be summarised as: "[D]" links look awful, difficult to associate a link directly with the image, longdesc doesn't cause catastrophic bugs in browsers, and "[D]" links are as bad as "click here"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:12): I think the first issue can be solved by using different link text or hiding it with CSS,
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:12): the next could possibly be solved using <figure><img><a rel=longdesc/></figure>,
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (06:13): and the third is countered by the argument that existing use of longdesc is more harmful
